channel.title: lwlies on SoCool | Ultimate Resource Favorites
channel.description: Recent content in lwlies on SoCool | Ultimate Resource Favorites

item.title: Little Monsters
item.description: Lupita Nyong’o defends a group of school kids from a zombie horde in Abe Forsythe’s tame comedy-horror.

item.title: Frozen 2
item.description: The siren call of two beloved, showtune-singing Disney princesses leads to a sequel lacking in ideas, emotion and drama.

item.title: Do Netflix’s varied playback speeds pose a threat to filmmakers?
item.description: Barely a week goes by without some minor-to-moderate kerfuffle surrounding Netflix and its plans for rapid expansion.

item.title: Elaine May is making a new movie, this is not a drill
item.description: Behold, the buried lede of the century: tucked away deep in a Deadline item about the goings-on around the awards circuit, reporter Pete Hammond blew open a story guaranteed to make cinephile heads start spinning around, Exorcist-style.

item.title: Old episodes of Friends are there (in cinemas) for you
item.description: This week The Hollywood Reporter reported that Fathom Events – the entertainment company known for programming special-engagement multiplex showings of opera, mainstream repertory film, and other deviations from the week’s new releases – will soon bring the small screen to the silver screen.

item.title: On Location: The church ruins from The Blood on Satan’s Claw
item.description: “Speak now, come now, rise now from the forest, from the furrows, from the fields and live!

item.title: The Academy is getting into streaming – and that could be good news
item.description: It’s a year of change on multiple fronts for the Academy Awards, from the renaming of Foreign Film as International Film to the ongoing Netflix question.

item.title: The star of A Nightmare on Elm Street 2 is reclaiming the film’s queerness
item.description: It should have been the role of a lifetime for 21-year-old Mark Patton, but playing the lead in A Nightmare on Elm Street 2: Freddy’s Revenge turned into a real-life nightmare for the budding actor – so much so that he ended up quitting Hollywood altogether.
